Row.Text: A Qajar official returns from a tour of other empires and publishes a travelogue to share his journey with the people. Yet keen readers complain that he has eschewed diplomatic conversations in favor of his own personal fascinations.
International dealings should be public knowledge.
More must be told of the habits of sloths.

The newly invented camera invites the Qajar people to see themselves and their world from new perspectives. Families pile into studios to formally immortalize their faces, while amateur photographers take their cameras into the world to capture more candid moments.
Through technology, one sees oneself anew.

The Achaemenid legacy reignites across the Qajar Empire. Artists, inspired by the grand works of their ancestors, take interest in ancient rock carvings, traditional depictions of power. Herein is a legacy of rule, they say — one that may be leveraged even today.
New royal carvings shall be added to the old ones.
Copies of the originals will be installed at the palace.
The more laudatory art, the better!

In the halls of the Qajar palace, life-sized portraits of royals gaze down upon passing visitors. The deep hues of the oils and incorporated symbols of power speak their legacy louder than the words their mouths once uttered.
Portraiture is a vital art form that thrives on patronage.
These expressive works are diplomats themselves.

Modern times require a modern army, and a prominent governor pushes novel ideas about the future of Qajar forces. He invites advisors from other empires to instruct his troops and commissions the translations of military manuals from abroad.
With these reforms, the Qajar will claim the world.

Through the thick scent of coffee, patrons of the ghahve khaneh hold lively debates over intense games of backgammon and chess. But when the ta'ziyeh begins, the shops fall silent. All gather to witness ancient stories, their songs, their movements, their lessons.
The takyeh preserves knowledge that cannot be forgotten.
These coffee-fueled arguments stimulate future change.
The old world and the new guide the empire forward together.

Territorial loss has plagued the Qajar Empire in the past — but no longer. A population once wrenched from its grasp is now restored. Yet restoration of former glory is only the first step to greatness.
A growing populace must be supported to be productive.
These victories speak to ingenuity among the generals.
All cities fall before the might of Xerxes.
The Russian general cautiously approaches the local khan, ready to accept his defeat. Suddenly shots ring out. No one breathes. Then the general slumps in his saddle, and slowly falls to the ground.
Now is the time to press the attack.
Qajar generals would never fall for such a ruse.

Within Eram Garden, the city’s chaos fades away. Trees murmur in the breeze. Waters ripple in the afternoon heat. Flowers exude heavenly scents. In the pavilion’s tiles, a poet’s words testify to the inspiration one may find here, if only one takes the time to sit still and listen.
Moments of peace recharge the soul.
The power of the garden delights all who visit.
Across the Qajar Empire, the railways are never quiet. Steam engines roar and whistles screech, a cacophony of profit running night and day to usher goods and people across shrinking distances.
The future is as bright as the gold upon which it is built.
The modern world is built upon rails.
The Good Doctor and the Tourist
Dr Rizal is invited to have coffee with a Qajar prince, recently returned from his own tour of foreign lands. They share their tales freely between them.
Ask of the operas he attended.
Ask of the great feasts he had.
